article.title: The VLA-COSMOS 3 GHz Large Project: Multiwavelength counterparts and the composition of the faint radio population

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the blue full line in Figure 1 represent?
choices: The area covered by the UltraVISTA survey.
The outer edge of the unmasked area, coincident with the Subaru Suprime Cam COSMOS field.
The masked regions due to the presence of saturated or bright sources.
The area covered by the Herschel Space Observatory.

multiple_choice_question.text: What trend is observed in the fraction of matched VLA 3 GHz sources as a function of signal-to-noise ratio?
choices: The fraction of matched sources decreases steadily with increasing signal-to-noise ratio.
The fraction of matched sources increases steadily with increasing signal-to-noise ratio.
The fraction of matched sources remains constant across all signal-to-noise ratios.
The fraction of matched sources increases with signal-to-noise ratio up to a point, then decreases.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the black wedge in Figure 6 represent?
choices: The area defined by Donley et al. (2012) for the selection of MIR-AGN in the color-color plane.
The region occupied by star-forming galaxies with spectroscopic redshifts.
The area where the IRAC colour distribution is different between the full sample and the subsample with IRAC-only counterparts.
The area where the bulk of sources with no redshift measurement are located.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the log (L1.4GHz/SFRIR) ratio discussed in the article?
choices: It quantifies the excess of radio emission relative to the star formation rates in host galaxies, indicating possible AGN activity.
It represents the redshift-dependent threshold used to identify star-forming galaxies with strong radio emission.
It defines the relationship between the 1.4 GHz rest-frame radio luminosity and the bolometric luminosity of the AGN.
It describes the efficiency of the 3-component SED fitting procedure in separating AGN and star-forming galaxy emission.
